posts.name: risho900
posts.cooked:
Hi. I‚Äôve read about in the past how teams are using the CANivore that can allow them to run two separate CAN buses on their robot. However, the CANivore to my understanding only works with CAN FD devices.

My question therefore: is there another way to accomplish something similar to this such as T-ing off the Rio?

So for example if my bot only used REV devices, is there a way I could have my drivebase motors be on a separate bus than all the mechanisms motors that all combine back at the end when going into the PDH ? Kinda like a blend of star + bus topology for the bus.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked: If all the devices have the same start and end point, no matter what the topology is in between, it‚Äôs all one bus. You might be able to do something clever to keep the other devices on the bus running should you lose a connection somewhere, but this won‚Äôt help with CAN utilization.

posts.name: risho900
posts.cooked: It‚Äôs not really utilization I‚Äôm worried about. Moreso just giving more options for wiring so it‚Äôs easier to visualize and diagnose. So for example with flipped swerves where motors sit under the belly pan, I‚Äôd prefer to have those on a different branch than all the other mechanisms above the pan.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked:
A true linear bus might be your best option, then. A lot of FRC teams make things that, while they are technically a linear bus, tend to ‚Äúlook like‚Äù a ring.

I‚Äôd say a star or something but I don‚Äôt necessarily know how well a CAN hub would behave in an FRC environment.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked:
Actually it looks like it‚Äôs been discussed here and people have gotten them to behave.

Looking for a CAN bus "hub" Electrical

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
At its core, CAN bus topology is just a big parallel circuit, here is a diagram to illustrate what we did this season which sounds similar to what you‚Äôre mentioning. note, we didnt use a CANivore.

Untitled drawing 960√ó720 20.6 KB

Untitled drawing 960√ó720 20.6 KB

Untitled drawing 960√ó720 20.6 KB

Each green line represents the CAN bus, notice how each individual mechanism feeds off a main line that connects to the RIO and other core components.  I dont have a photo of it in the robot itself but here is a photo of the robot so you can get an idea of how it can be separated. This did help a bit when we had some addressing issues in CAN , made troubleshooting way easier than the typical big loop setup.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked: Thank you for the picture! This is what I meant when I said a true linear bus.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Normally you would place the rio and the phh/pdp at the two ends of the bus (eg connect the pdp/pdh up past the pivot mech.  This is because they each contain the proper termination resistor to prevent signal reflection which happens at the end of an unterminated bus such as shown in your diagram.

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked: Good catch. You can turn off the one in the pdp/pdh and use your own at the other end if you want, but the RIO one is built in.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked: Honestly, this is just something i missed in the diagram but iirc, the actual robot is wired this way.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
The important thing when using this type of topology (which is one of my favorites tbf) to keep it stable is just to make sure the ‚Äústubs‚Äù/branches to the individuals devices is as short as possible, like 1ft at the absolute max. The issue with the topology vs the more traditional daisy-chain is that because of the branches/stubs ending at a high-impedance point, it can cause more signal reflections, which will reduce how efficiently the whole bus runs. This isn‚Äôt a problem for the typical FRC CAN Bus because its only 1Mbps, but can be more of a problem on faster buses such as the CANivore‚Äôs 10Mbps bus.

Another good example is RAM on a PC. If you have a dual channel CPU but the Motherboard has 4 slots, its because each channel is wired to two of those slots. The reason manuals will specify which slots to use, even within the same channel, is because you want the ram itself to be at the very end of that motherboard trace (aka wire). If you put the RAM in the other slot, then there is some more trace going past the ram that just ends at the slot connector (aka is high impedance) and that can again cause signal reflections which could slow down how fast your CPU‚Äôs Memory Controller can access your RAM.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: usually not a fatal error, but it can cause dropped packets/retransmissions, so definitely not ideal.
